channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Taiwan, Voters Choose President as China Tensions Loom
item.description: Taiwan’s vice president, whose party has emphasized the island’s sovereignty, defeated an opposition party that favors reviving engagement with China.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwan’s vice president, Lai Ching-te, won the island’s presidential election on Saturday.

item.title: One Man’s Mission to Revive an Indigenous Language in Argentina
item.description: Blas Jaime has spent nearly two decades resurrecting Chaná, an Indigenous language in Argentina that he learned from his mother.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba and Sebastián López Brach
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Blas Omar Jaime has, in many ways, placed the Chaná Indigenous group back on the map.

item.title: U.S.-Led Strikes Leave Yemen Back on the Brink of War
item.description: Yemen’s Houthi militia, shaped by years of civil war, says that it welcomes a battle with the United States and that strikes will not stop its Red Sea attacks.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Saeed Al-Batati
item.media:description: A protest in Sana, Yemen, on Friday against a U.S.-led operation targeting Houthi military sites.

item.title: U.N. Warns Gaza Is Heading for Famine as Specter of Wider War Looms
item.description: Officials of the Iran-backed Houthi militia in Yemen threatened to respond to American-led airstrikes over the past two days.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Palestinian children line up for a meal in Rafah, southern Gaza, where food is scarce, last month.

item.title: China Failed to Sway Taiwan’s Election. What Happens Now?
item.description: Beijing loathes the new president, Lai Ching-te. He aims to protect the status quo with caution and American help, but tensions are likely to rise.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Lai Ching-te in Taipei after his win on Saturday, a third successive victory for the Democratic Progressive Party.

item.title: India’s Court System Is Hopelessly Backed Up
item.description: With 50 million criminal and civil cases pending, it would take 300 years to clear the country’s judicial backlog.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Elke Scholiers
item.media:description: Lawyers outside the Delhi High Court. The number of pending cases in the Indian judicial system has doubled over the past two decades, to more than 50 million.

item.title: Threatened by Premier League Fan Zones, Burger Vans Hold Their Ground
item.description: As Premier League clubs create fan zones to collect yet more money from stadium visitors, a local economy of food trucks, pubs and small restaurants is holding its ground.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tony Aujla’s Burger Bar outside Villa Park in Birmingham, England. Mr. Aujla has been a fixture outside the stadium, in one place or another, for more than four decades.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern, Former New Zealand Prime Minister, Is Married
item.description: New Zealand’s pathbreaking former prime minister became a global celebrity noted for, among other things, a very long engagement.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Felicity Jean Photography, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An official photograph from the wedding of New Zealand’s former prime minister Jacinda Ardern and Clarke Gayford on Saturday in Hawke’s Bay, New Zealand.

item.title: Ecuador’s Attorney General Took on Drug Gangs. Then Chaos Broke Out.
item.description: Explosive revelations by the country’s top prosecutor showed links between cartels and officials, a move that might be “kicking the hornet’s nest.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:description: Soldiers detaining a man after curfew on Friday morning in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

item.title: Russia Regains Upper Hand in Ukraine’s East as Kyiv’s Troops Flag
item.description: Ukrainians are weary, short of ammunition and outnumbered, and their prospects look bleak. “We can stop them for now, but who knows,” one soldier said. “Tomorrow or the next day, maybe we can’t stop them.”
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier from the 68th Brigade at a trench 500 yards from Russian positions in Ukraine’s eastern Luhansk region, earlier this week.

item.title: Taiwan Election: Why It Matters, and What It Could Mean for U.S. and China
item.description: Voters headed to the polls to choose a new president who could alter the complicated, risky balance between Taiwan, China and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, John Liu, Chris Buckley and Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Tainan, Taiwan, for the Nationalist Party’s presidential candidate, Hou Yu-ih. The presidential race on Saturday is expected to be close.

item.title: Russia Launches Large-Scale Missile Attack on Ukraine
item.description: The assault was in line with a wider air campaign that Russia began in late December, seeking to wear down Ukrainian air defenses.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: People taking shelter inside a metro station during an air-raid alert on Saturday in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Macron’s New French Cabinet Features Veteran Politicians and Some Surprises
item.description: A reshuffle brought in a handful of new ministers, including a high-profile conservative and a Europe-focused foreign minister. But several key officials remained.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: From left, the government officials Carole Grandjean, Amélie Oudéa-Castéra and Gabriel Attal in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Pope Cites Bronchitis as He Skips Speaking to Audiences at the Vatican
item.description: Instead, the pontiff’s words were handed out in written form. He seemed to be in good spirits, though his health has become an increasing concern.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving for his weekly general audience at the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: Lloyd Austin Confronts the Perils of Being a Private Man in a Public Job
item.description: President Biden said his defense secretary made an error in judgment in not keeping the White House informed of his hospitalization. But keeping a low profile has long defined the Pentagon chief.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, the former commander of United States Central Command, brought 40 years of service with him when he took the top Pentagon job in 2021.

item.title: Antihero Worship
item.description: The Emmy Awards are next week. Does it matter if you like the characters on the nominated shows?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Russian Dissident’s Fraught Path to Canadian Citizenship
item.description: Maria Kartasheva was sentenced in absentia by a Moscow court for criticizing the war in Ukraine, threatening her citizenship application in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Dave Chan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Kartasheva at home in Ottawa. A Russian dissident, she was sentenced by a Moscow court to eight years in prison for spreading “false information” about the war in Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Leads Second Strike Against Houthis in Yemen
item.description: The military fired at a target in response to rising attacks on Red Sea shipping, which the Houthis linked to the war between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim, Helene Cooper and Thomas Fuller
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A protest in Sana, Yemen, on Friday against the operation to safeguard Red Sea shipping with U.S. and British airstrikes on Houthi military sites.

item.title: Tesla and Volvo to Pause Production in Europe After Red Sea Attacks
item.description: The carmakers said they would suspend production at their plants in Germany and Belgium because of supply chain snarls linked to the attacks in the Red Sea.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Tesla said its factory in Grünheide, Germany, will temporarily suspend production starting Jan. 29.

item.title: Gaza is Facing Yet Another Communications Blackout
item.description: It is the ninth blackout the enclave has endured since the war began in early October.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Palestinians searching for missing people under the rubble after Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis, southern Gaza, on Friday.

item.title: How Women’s Soccer Is Embracing Mental Health
item.description: Elite soccer didn’t always welcome players’ requests for help. Scandals, attitudes and support programs are changing that.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.category: United States Women's National Soccer Team
item.media:description: Sinead Farrelly at the 2023 Women’s World Cup in Australia, far from her darkest days.

item.title: C.I.A. Homes In on Hamas Leadership, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: A new task force at the spy agency is also working to boost intelligence collection on hostages still held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral in Israel for a mother and two daughters killed in the Hamas attacks. A C.I.A. task force was assembled to gather information after the Oct. 7 attack in Israel.

item.title: With Genocide Case Against Israel, South Africa Challenges Western-led Order
item.description: After arguing its genocide case against Israel at the International Court of Justice, South Africa won praise for standing up for Palestinians under Israeli bombardment in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Remko De Waal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: South Africa’s minister of justice, Ronald Lamola, and the South African ambassador to the Netherlands, Vusimuzi Madonsela, in the International Court of Justice on Thursday.

item.title: After U.S.-Led Strikes in Yemen, How Wide Will the Middle East War Get?
item.description: With the U.S.-led attacks in Yemen, there is no longer a question of whether the Israel-Hamas war will escalate into a wider conflict. The question is whether it can be contained.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, David E. Sanger, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Newly recruited Houthi fighters during a parade in December in Amran Province, Yemen.

item.title: It’s a monster election year. Don’t let the horse race distract you.
item.description: Our institutions are in decline, and we need to pay attention.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Institutions, like the London Underground, exist so that complex processes can become automatic.

item.title: What to Know About the ICJ and the Genocide Case
item.description: The United Nations’ highest judicial body held two days of hearings this week in a case by South Africa accusing Israel of committing genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and John Eligon
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators watching proceedings on Friday on a screen outside of the International Court of Justice in The Hague, Netherlands.

item.title: Airstrikes in Yemen Are ‘Extremely Unlikely’ to Deter Houthis, Experts Say
item.description: U.S.-led airstrikes in Yemen could play into the agenda of the Houthis, who have built their legitimacy on hostility toward the United States and Israel, scholars said.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Saeed Al-Batati
item.media:description: Newly recruited Houthi fighters in Sana, Yemen, in December.

item.title: U.S.-Led Airstrikes in Yemen Draw Fury From Iran
item.description: Other critics also included militias allied with Iran, as well as Oman, a U.S. ally that often mediates between the Houthis and international parties.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A seized ship, the Galaxy Leader, seen off the Yemeni coast in December.

item.title: Netflix Film’s Removal Shows Power of India’s Hindu Right Wing
item.description: The movie “Annapoorani” was about a female chef overcoming caste prejudice. Hindu activists said it hurt their feelings.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Netflix pulled a movie that some Hindus considered hurtful.

item.title: Accused of Genocide, Israelis See Reversal of Reality. Palestinians See Justice.
item.description: Israel stands accused of committing genocide in Gaza. To Israelis, the charge is a perversion of history. But for Palestinians it creates a fleeting sense of justice.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators outside the International Court of Justice in The Hague on Friday.

item.title: Sunak Pledges $3 Billion in Military Aid to Ukraine
item.description: The annual British package is about $255 million more than in the past two years and is part of an effort to reassure Kyiv amid concerns about a potential shortfall in Western support.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelenskiy of Ukraine and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain in Kyiv on Friday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: What’s at stake in Taiwan’s election.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters cheer during a rally for the Democratic Progressive Party in Taipei.

item.title: Taiwan Party, Reviled by China, Faces Test of its Staying Power
item.description: The Democratic Progressive Party has transformed Taiwan into a bastion against Chinese power. Now it is promising a mix of change and continuity.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:description: The Grand Hotel Taipei in Taipei, Taiwan, last month. The Democratic Progressive Party was formed in the hotel’s ballroom in 1986.

item.title: Who Are the Houthis and Why Is the U.S. Attacking Them?
item.description: The Iranian-backed rebel group has launched dozens of attacks on commercial ships in the Red Sea since the war between Israel and Hamas started.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Newly recruited Houthi fighters march past a large image of their leader, Abdul-Malik al-Houthi, in December.

item.title: U.S. Missiles Strike Houthi Targets in Yemen After Red Sea Attacks
item.description: The American-led strikes came in response to more than two dozen Houthi drone and missile attacks against commercial shipping in the Red Sea since the Israel-Hamas war began.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Newly recruited Houthi fighters on Thursday in Sana, Yemen.

item.title: Israel Faces Accusation of Genocide as South Africa Brings Case to U.N. Court
item.description: Arguing to a packed courtroom at the International Court of Justice in The Hague, South African lawyers cited the words of Israeli officials as evidence in their case. Israel has categorically denied the accusation.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin, Hiba Yazbek and Thomas Fuller
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Inside the International Court of Justice on Thursday.

item.title: Drought Touches a Quarter of Humanity, U.N. Says, Disrupting Lives Globally
item.description: The crisis, worsened partly by climate change, has been accompanied by soaring food prices and could have consequences for hunger, elections and migration worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
item.media:description: The shrinking Lake Titicaca, between Peru and Bolivia in the Andes, is Latin America’s largest freshwater basin.

item.title: Blinken Talks a Grand Vision for Mideast Peace but Hits a Wall in Israel
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken conducted marathon diplomacy around the region, but Israeli leaders, focused on war with Hamas, showed no interest in meeting demands like Palestinian statehood.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on a military plane as he departed for Bahrain from Israel on Wednesday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Taiwan Prepares to Vote
item.description: Also, an interview with Naomi Osaka.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters in Taipei.

item.title: Red Double-Decker Bus Catches Fire During London Rush Hour
item.description: There were no injuries, and the London Fire Brigade said it would investigate the cause of the fire on the iconic red double-decker bus.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina

item.title: Heiress Seeks 50 Austrians to Give Away $27 Million
item.description: Marlene Engelhorn has sent invitations to 10,000 Austrians. Once that group is narrowed to 50, it will spend six weekends this year discussing the best way to spend the money.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Mashid Mohadjerin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marlene Engelhorn is part of a small movement of the superrich who want not only to redistribute their money, but also to challenge the structures that allowed them to inherit their riches in the first place.

item.title: Israel and Hamas Are in Talks to Deliver Medicine to Hostages in Gaza
item.description: More than 120 hostages are believed to still be held in Gaza and many suffer from health conditions that require regular medical care.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: An Israeli protester in Tel Aviv, calling for the release of hostages held in Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Scotland, Joining England and Wales, Will Restrict Bully XL Dogs
item.description: The dogs, seen as dangerous by many, will have to be muzzled in public, neutered and microchipped, among other regulations.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Jacob King/PA Images via Getty Images
item.media:description: Scotland will strictly regulate bully XL dogs, after England and Wales passed similar measures.

item.title: What Happens When There Is No Food: Experts Say Severe Malnutrition Could Set in Swiftly in Gaza
item.description: Nutrition experts say the progression from hunger to severe malnutrition can be rapid, especially in children.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Making bread at tents amid the rubble of a destroyed building in Rafah, in southern Gaza.

item.title: U.S. Military Aid to Ukraine Was Poorly Tracked, Pentagon Report Says
item.description: The report found that American officials and diplomats had failed to quickly or fully account for all of the nearly 40,000 weapons sent to the front.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian infantry officer firing a rocket-propelled grenade toward Russian positions near Marinka, in eastern Ukraine, in May.

item.title: Iranian Navy Says It Seized an Oil Tanker Off the Coast of Oman
item.description: The same vessel was involved last year in the U.S. government seizure of Iranian oil that was being transported in violation of American sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: An oil tanker passing through the Strait of Hormuz in 2018.

item.title: Finland Extends Closure of Border With Russia
item.description: Late last year, Finland accused Moscow of facilitating an influx of migrants and shut its land border crossings with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: The Vaalimaa crossing between Finland and Russia last month. The countries’ relationship deteriorated after Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Papua New Guinea Declares State of Emergency After Riots, Looting
item.description: There were signs the authorities had regained some control, but the extent of damage and casualties from the unrest remained unclear.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Cottrell
item.media:description: People carrying out goods from shops in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea, on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Adesanya of M.M.A. Fame Avoids Drunk-Driving Conviction
item.description: Within hours, the former middleweight mixed martial arts champion risked more legal trouble by posting provocative content on social media.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Israel Adesanya during an Ultimate Fighting Championship event in Sydney, Australia, last year.

item.title: Gaza Aid Faces Lengthy Inspections and Logistical Issues
item.description: Obstacles at two border crossings are exacerbating a growing humanitarian crisis, according to two U.S. senators and officials with the U.N. and other groups.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Adam Sella and Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Palestinians lining up for free food in Rafah, in the Gaza Strip, on Tuesday. A humanitarian crisis in the territory is worsening, aid officials say.

item.title: Blinken Meets el-Sisi in Egypt to Discuss Palestinians in Gaza
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state also planned to talk about how to prevent the violence in the Mideast from escalating further, as Iran-backed militias ramp up attacks.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, left, met with President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt in Cairo on Thursday.

item.title: Taiwan Democracy Is Loud and Proud
item.description: At the island’s election rallies, warming up the crowd for candidates is crucial. “You have to light a fire in their hearts,” one host says.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Houthi attacks in the Red Sea.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: British Ministry of Defense, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by Britain’s Ministry of Defense on Wednesday, taken from the bridge of the H.M.S. Diamond, shows missiles fired in the Red Sea.

item.title: Hamas Says Hostages Won’t Go Home Alive While Israeli Forces Remain in Gaza
item.description: Netanyahu faces growing pressure to get the more than 100 hostages still held in Gaza home safely.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A mass public prayer calling for the hostages held in the Gaza Strip to be released in Jerusalem’s Old City.

item.title: U.S. and British Forces Fend Off Houthi Attack in Red Sea
item.description: American officials and their allies warned that there would be consequences for the Houthis, the Iranian-backed armed group that has disrupted shipping in the Red Sea.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Thomas Fuller and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A ship transits the Suez Canal toward the Red Sea on Wednesday.

item.title: Standoff at Presidential Palace Shows Poland’s Right Won’t Go Quietly
item.description: The incident escalated a campaign by the ousted Law and Justice party to resist the transfer of power after it lost its parliamentary majority in October.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Protesters gathering to support former Interior Minister Mariusz Kaminski in front of the Presidential Palace in Warsaw on Wednesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: The Fight Against Houthi Rebels
item.description: Preview: Also, violence in Ecuador.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Models of Houthi-made drones on display in Sana’a, Yemen on Wednesday.

item.title: How a TV Show Forced Britain’s Devastating Post Office Scandal Into the Light
item.description: After years of delays, victims of one of the U.K.’s worst miscarriages of justice are finally being exonerated — thanks to a TV drama.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Mr Bates vs the Post Office (TV Program)

item.title: Al Shabab Terrorist Group Captures U.N. Helicopter in Somalia
item.description: Somali officials said the helicopter was carrying nine passengers, one of whom was killed. The Horn of Africa nation is now grappling with how to rescue hostages from a group known for mistreating them.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Fighters with Al Shabab in 2010. The group has been terrorizing the Horn of Africa region for about a decade and a half.

item.title: Ecuador Shaken by Days of Terror After Gang Leader’s Disappearance
item.description: Vowing to bring peace back to a shattered country, President Daniel Noboa has deployed the military to take on what he calls “terrorist” groups.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: The police detained on Wednesday in Guayaquil, Ecuador, men they said had been part of an armed group that temporarily took over a TV broadcast.
